Issues.Title: refactor(ivy): move classMap interpolation logic internally
Issues.Body:
Adds the new `classMapInterpolate1` through `classMapInterpolate8` instructions which handle interpolations inside the `class` attribute and moves the interpolation logic internally. This allows us to remove the `interpolationX` instructions in a follow-up PR.

These changes also add an error if an interpolation is encountered inside a `style` tag (e.g. `style="width: {{value}}"`). Up until now this would actually generate valid instructions, because `styleMap` goes through the same code path as `classMap` which does support interpolation. At runtime, however, `styleMap` would set invalid styles that look like `<div style="0:w;1:i;2:d;3:t;4:h;5::;7:1;">`. In `ViewEngine` interpolations inside `style` weren't supported either, however there we'd output invalid styles like `<div style="unsafe">`, even if the content was trusted.

**Note:** it looks like the Codefresh failure isn't due to these changes.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(ivy): move classMap interpolation logic internally" (#31211)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): include type parameter for `ngBaseDef` declaration
Issues.Body:
When a class uses Angular decorators such as `@Input`, `@Output` and
friends without an Angular class decorator, they are compiled into a
static `ngBaseDef` field on the class, with the TypeScript declaration
of the class being altered to declare the `ngBaseDef` field to be of type
`…µ…µBaseDef`. This type however requires a generic type parameter that
corresponds with the type of the class, however the compiler did not
provide this type parameter. As a result, compiling a program where such
invalid `ngBaseDef` declarations are present will result in compilation
errors.

This commit fixes the problem by providing the generic type parameter.

Fixes #31160
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): include type parameter for `ngBaseDef` declaration" (#31210)

Issues.Title: build: use bazel from node modules

The goal of https://github.com/angular/components/commit/2ce5ffd56b70c3791331ceedeadc1f1f6daf3924 was to avoid the use of Bazel through the `node_modules`
because it adds unnecessary code overhead, slows down CI and means that
some tools need to be installed multiple times (such as `yarn`). Unfortunately
when building a release with Bazel right now, the bazel workspace status script
depends on the global `node` binary. This means that we need to bring in Node
when running with the `--config=release` flag.. Since that causes inconsistent behavior
and just complicates the setup, we are using Bazel through Yarn for now. Similar to how
we did it for `angular/angular` with https://github.com/angular/angular/commit/8fc4ae51fb66d14f6dc82712a536c3842205fc6d.

We need to revisit this overall approach in the future.. but for now this seems to be the
simplest approach and we don't want too much effort into this yet. Seems like a general

The one on the right is a mat-select using virtual-scroll. This one has several issues. I will just describe one here which I believe it's not been filed yet.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Select an option from the mat-select on the Right. The option is displayed fine once the selector gets closed.

2. Now open again the mat-select on the right. The selector shows nothing (#15902) but we let's continue working.

3. With the "blank" selector opened, scroll down using the mouse wheel. You will see options are displayed again. Scroll to some position where the "selected" value is not longer visible (outside the MatOption instances used by the virtual scroll). Now Press "ESC". 

4. Boom! The selector goes away (expected) but, despite the mat-select has a "value" set, the component shows nothing.
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

If we hit "ESC" o "click outside the mat-select", the control should always display the selected value, no matter if it's using default or virtual scroll.


#### Actual Behavior

The selected option is no longer displayed (but it's still set).

Obs:

1) "mat-select" seems to re-calculate its internal "selectionModel" and "empty" states once the selector is closed. It calculates this state using the available MatOptions which, of course, are not the full-set of options when using virtual scroll.

2) I don't know if this is a "virtual-scroll" bug or a "mat-select" bug but, anyway, the combination of both is crashing (somehow).

#### Environment

- Angular: 8.0.1
- CDK/Material: 8.0.1
- Browser(s): Chrome 74
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10

Issues.Title: fix(bottom-sheet): DOM nodes not cleaned up if view container is destroyed mid-animation
Issues.Body:
Along the same lines as #16309.

Currently the bottom sheet's cleanup logic is tied to its exit animation completing. This usually isn't a problem since by default the bottom sheet is attached to the application ref, however if the consumer has set a viewContainerRef and that ref is destroyed mid-animation, the exit animation event will never fire.
